sentence.idiomatic: Lately my computer is always malfunctioning.
This television has too many things wrong with it, there is no point in repairing it.
That same old problem he has come back again, he needs to rest for a few days.
It's too cold, the car won't start.
If you replace the motor, the motorcycle should be able to start.

word.literal: second half of a game or contest

sentence.idiomatic: The Rockets launched an attack in the second half.
This angle is not very good, I'll adjust it a bit.
It's too noisy, turn the volume a bit lower.
My bike brakes are not very effective, can you adjust them for me?
The screen suddenly started flickering like crazy.
When you were shaking out your clothes before--it must have been then that your wallet fell out.
As soon as you get nervous your voice starts to tremble.
Have you fastened your seatbelt? The car is about to accelerate.
When he was almost at the finish, he suddenly sped up and caught up to the athlete in front of him.
In the last little while we have been accelerating production of this mobile phone model.
Wait for me a moment, I'm going to change my clothes.
Would you be able to change seats with me?
He got a new keyboard, and types much faster now.
Tomorrow we will set off at precisely seven o'clock.
The meeting starts at nine o'clock. Please everyone be in attendance on time.
Yesterday I didn't arrive on time. He was a little angry.
Sir, there's something wrong with my motorbike. Can you take a look for me?
What the problem?
When the weather is cold it is difficult to start.
Let me take a look... I'll adjust your carburetor a bit.
Yeah, lately when I start it up it shakes quite a bit. Plus, when I accelerate I don't feel any power.
Hmm. That would be your spark plugs. You need to replace them. How long has it been since you changed your oil?
I don't know...
You need to schedule an oil change every 3,000 to 5,000 kilometers.
Oh, really. Now I know.
OK. Drive it for a bit and see how it is. If you have any problems, come back and see me.
Much better! Thank you sir!
